toolbox.description: Tools used to pre-tagging and optimizing line vertices to help centerline and other tools to produce better results.

tools.name: Pre-tagging
tools.info: Tagging lines by examining lines existence in CHM rasters

parameters.description: Input forest line center shapefile which will be segmented and attributed.

Input CHM raster file used as basis for mapping forest lines and their footprint. This layer should be projected in any Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) coordinate system. The data should be preferably derived from high resolution LiDAR or photogrammetry (>25 pts/m²).
Input raster image used to exclude canopy from line footprint.
Input raster image used to calculate the cost corridor.
Polygons of different LiDAR sources coverage with acquisition year
Maximum processing distance from input lines. A large search radius may increase processing times whereas a small radius may cause undesired clipping.
Output features that will be tagged.

tools.name: Vertex Optimization
tools.info: Relocating line intersections to seismic line paths

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used to calculate the least cost path.
Maximum processing distance from input lines. A large search radius may increase processing times whereas a small radius may cause undesired clipping.
Output optimized center-line shapefile.

toolbox.description: Tools used to map center lines and footprint polygons of linear disturbances in forests using a Canopy Height Model (CHM) as reference.

tools.name: Canopy Cost Raster
tools.info: Creates a canopy raster and a cost raster from a CHM input raster. The output rasters are used for subsequent FLM tools.

parameters.description: Input CHM raster file used as basis for mapping forest lines and their footprint. This layer should be projected in any Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) coordinate system. The data should be preferably derived from high resolution LiDAR or photogrammetry (>25 pts/m²).
Height threshold in meters above which CHM pixels are considered canopy.

Radius of canopy influence in the cost raster. This factor smooths the canopy in the cost raster which helps to prevent gaps in sparsely vegetated areas (e.g. wetlands) to be incorrectly identified as footprint. A large search radius (>=5m) may cause excessive smoothing of the cost raster which can lead to least cost paths ignoring forest-line nuances in sparsely vegetated forests. A small radius (<=1m) may cause the least cost path to cut corners through small gaps in sparse vegetation as well as avoid small obstacles that should not affect overall line shape.

Maximum euclidean distance from canopy. This is a second smoothing factor which helps to position the forest line shape in the center of the line footprint. An excessively small (<=1m) or large (>20m) value may cause the center line to be positioned close to one of the edges of the footprint.

Ratio of importance between canopy search radius and euclidean distance. A value close to zero (0) prioritizes search radius whereas a value close to one (1) prioritizes euclidean distance. A small value (<=0.1) may cause the forest lines to miss nuances in sparsely vegetated terrain whereas a big value (>=0.5) may overemphasize turns in complex trails. This factor influences final footprint size in a minor way.

Affects the cost of vegetated areas in an exponential fashion. A low (<=1) exponent may lead to lines cutting through corners, whereas a large (>=3) exponent may lead to least cost paths completely avoiding narrow lines.
Output raster classified as canopy (1) and non-canopy (0).
Output cost raster used in subsequent FLM tools for least-cost analysis.

tools.name: Center Line
tools.info: Determines the least cost path between vertices of the input lines.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used to calculate the least cost path.
Maximum processing distance from input lines. A large search radius may increase processing times whereas a small radius may cause undesired clipping.

If set to True, will process each segment between each vertex of the input lines separately. If set to False, will process each line from start to end ignoring midpoints. The default is True, since it is assumed that the input lines for this tool are lines manually digitized at regional-scale with sparse vertices at a fine-scale. If using fine-scale (1:1,000) lines as input this may be set to False.
Output center-line shapefile.

tools.name: Line Footprint
tools.info: Creates footprint polygons for each input line based on a least cost corridor method and individual line thresholds.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used to exclude canopy from line footprint.
Input raster image used to calculate the least cost corridor.
Name of the field (within the input lines) that indicates the least cost corridor thresholds (LCCT).
The least cost corridor thresholds (LCCT).
Maximum processing width for input lines. A large value may increase processing times whereas a small value may cause undesired clipping.
Range used for cell erosion before final polygons are generated. Useful to remove small artifacts.  If the cell size is 1m or larger then set this as zero.

If set to False, will process each line from start to end ignoring midpoints. If set to True, will process each segment between each vertex of the input lines separately. The default is False, since it is assumed that the input lines for this tool are manually corrected center-lines. If using regional-scale (1:20,000) lines as input this may be set to True.
Output footprint polygons.

tools.name: Dynamic Line Footprint(Full)
tools.info: Creates dynamic footprint polygons for each input line based on a least cost corridor method and individual line canopy thresholds and cost raster.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used calculate the surrounding forest elevation percentile, create canopy and cost raster.
Maximum processing width for input lines. A large value may increase processing times whereas a small value may cause undesired clipping.
Range used for cell erosion before final polygons are generated. Useful to remove small artifacts.  If the cell size is 1m or larger then set this as zero.

If set to False, will process each line from start to end ignoring midpoints. If set to True, will process each segment between each vertex of the input lines separately. The default is False, since it is assumed that the input lines for this tool are manually corrected center-lines. If using regional-scale (1:20,000) lines as input this may be set to True.
Output footprint polygons.
Offset distance from input lines.
The Nth percentile of the surrounding forest.
Apply % on calculating Canopy Threshold height from Canopy percentile elevation.

Radius of canopy influence in the cost raster. This factor smooths the canopy in the cost raster which helps to prevent gaps in sparsely vegetated areas (e.g. wetlands) to be incorrectly identified as footprint. A large search radius (>=5m) may cause excessive smoothing of the cost raster which can lead to least cost paths ignoring forest-line nuances in sparsely vegetated forests. A small radius (<=1m) may cause the least cost path to cut corners through small gaps in sparse vegetation as well as avoid small obstacles that should not affect overall line shape.

Maximum euclidean distance from canopy. This is a second smoothing factor which helps to position the forest line shape in the center of the line footprint. An excessively small (<=1m) or large (>20m) value may cause the center line to be positioned close to one of the edges of the footprint.

Ratio of importance between canopy search radius and euclidean distance. A value close to zero (0) prioritizes search radius whereas a value close to one (1) prioritizes euclidean distance. A small value (<=0.1) may cause the forest lines to miss nuances in sparsely vegetated terrain whereas a big value (>=0.5) may overemphasize turns in complex trails. This factor influences final footprint size in a minor way.

Affects the cost of vegetated areas in an exponential fashion. A low (<=1) exponent may lead to lines cutting through corners, whereas a large (>=3) exponent may lead to least cost paths completely avoiding narrow lines.

toolbox.description: Tools used to generate attributes in the lines created with the Mapping Tools.

tools.name: Forest Line Attributes
tools.info: Calculates a series of attributes related to forest line shape, size and microtopography. Line-derived attributes include: length, bearing, orientation and sinuosity; Polygon-derived attributes include: area, average width, perimeter and perimeter-area ratio; CHM-derived attributes include: average vegetation height, vegetation volume and vegetation roughness.

parameters.description: Input forest line center shapefile which will be segmented and attributed.
Input forest line footprint shapefile used to derive spatial attributes.
Input canopy height model raster used to derive microtopography attributes.

How the input lines are segmented for attribution: IN-FEATURES, the input features are attributed without subdivisions; WHOLE-LINE, the entire extent of each line is attributed without subdivisions; LINE-CROSSINGS, each line is split at line intersections; ARBITRARY, each line is segmented using an arbitrary length.
Arbitrary segment length (m). If the Sampling Type field is not set as ARBITRARY this field is ignored.
Tolerance radius (m) used to split lines. If the Sampling Type field is set as WHOLE-LINE this field is ignored.
Maximum line width (m) used to search for surrounding footprint.
Output features that will be created.

tools.name: Raster Line Attributes
tools.info: Samples a raster image along lines and assigns cell statistics to each line.

parameters.description: Input forest line center shapefile which will be segmented and attributed.
Input raster image that will be sampled to attribute the input lines.

How the input lines are segmented for attribution: IN-FEATURES, the input features are attributed without subdivisions; WHOLE-LINE, the entire extent of each line is attributed without subdivisions; LINE-CROSSINGS, each line is split at line intersections; ARBITRARY, each line is segmented using an arbitrary length.
Sampling interval along input lines in meters.
Arbitrary segment length (m). If the Sampling Type field is not set as ARBITRARY this field is ignored.
Tolerance radius (m) used to split lines. If the Sampling Type field is set as WHOLE-LINE this field is ignored.
Method used to handle samples when attributing lines: Minimum, Maximum, Mean, Standard Deviation, Median, Mode, or Range.
Output features that will be created.

toolbox.description: Helpful tools to prepare inputs for the Mapping Tools.

tools.name: Clip Shape By Raster
tools.info: Extracts input features that overlay raster cells which are not NoData. This is useful to prepare input forest lines for corridor analysis, since vertices must overlap with valid cells for least cost methods.

parameters.description: Input features to be clipped.
Input raster used to clip the input features.
Number of cells to shrink in order to avoid raster edge contact.
Output features that will be created.

tools.name: Split By Polygon
tools.info: Splits the input lines where they intersect the edges of the input polygons.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile to be split.
Input polygon shapefile that is used to split the input lines.
Output features that will be created.

tools.name: Zonal Threshold
tools.info: Assigns corridor thresholds to the input lines based on their surrounding canopy density.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile for which each feature will be assigned an unique corridor threshold.
Name of the field (within the input lines) that indicates the corridor thresholds.
Input canopy raster used to estimate canopy density.
Search radius around line features where zonal statistics are calculated.
Minimum value for corridor threshold.
Maximum value for corridor threshold.
Output features that will be created.

tools.name: Dynamic Canopy Threshold
tools.info: Compute dynamic canopy threshold for each input line and update attributes.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used calculate the surrounding forest elevation percentile, create canopy and cost raster.

If set to False, will process each line from start to end ignoring midpoints. If set to True, will process each segment between each vertex of the input lines separately. The default is False, since it is assumed that the input lines for this tool are manually corrected center-lines. If using regional-scale (1:20,000) lines as input this may be set to True.
Offset distance from input lines.
The Nth percentile of the surrounding forest.
Apply % on calculating Canopy Threshold height from Canopy percentile elevation.

Radius of canopy influence in the cost raster. This factor smooths the canopy in the cost raster which helps to prevent gaps in sparsely vegetated areas (e.g. wetlands) to be incorrectly identified as footprint. A large search radius (>=5m) may cause excessive smoothing of the cost raster which can lead to least cost paths ignoring forest-line nuances in sparsely vegetated forests. A small radius (<=1m) may cause the least cost path to cut corners through small gaps in sparse vegetation as well as avoid small obstacles that should not affect overall line shape.

Maximum euclidean distance from canopy. This is a second smoothing factor which helps to position the forest line shape in the center of the line footprint. An excessively small (<=1m) or large (>20m) value may cause the center line to be positioned close to one of the edges of the footprint.

Ratio of importance between canopy search radius and euclidean distance. A value close to zero (0) prioritizes search radius whereas a value close to one (1) prioritizes euclidean distance. A small value (<=0.1) may cause the forest lines to miss nuances in sparsely vegetated terrain whereas a big value (>=0.5) may overemphasize turns in complex trails. This factor influences final footprint size in a minor way.

Affects the cost of vegetated areas in an exponential fashion. A low (<=1) exponent may lead to lines cutting through corners, whereas a large (>=3) exponent may lead to least cost paths completely avoiding narrow lines.

tools.name: Dynamic Line Footprint(Polygon)
tools.info: Creates dynamic footprint polygons for each input line based on a least cost corridor method and individual line canopy thresholds and cost raster.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used calculate the surrounding forest elevation percentile, create canopy and cost raster.
Maximum processing width for input lines. A large value may increase processing times whereas a small value may cause undesired clipping.
Range used for cell erosion before final polygons are generated. Useful to remove small artifacts.  If the cell size is 1m or larger then set this as zero.

If set to False, will process each line from start to end ignoring midpoints. If set to True, will process each segment between each vertex of the input lines separately. The default is False, since it is assumed that the input lines for this tool are manually corrected center-lines. If using regional-scale (1:20,000) lines as input this may be set to True.
Output footprint polygons.

Radius of canopy influence in the cost raster. This factor smooths the canopy in the cost raster which helps to prevent gaps in sparsely vegetated areas (e.g. wetlands) to be incorrectly identified as footprint. A large search radius (>=5m) may cause excessive smoothing of the cost raster which can lead to least cost paths ignoring forest-line nuances in sparsely vegetated forests. A small radius (<=1m) may cause the least cost path to cut corners through small gaps in sparse vegetation as well as avoid small obstacles that should not affect overall line shape.

Maximum euclidean distance from canopy. This is a second smoothing factor which helps to position the forest line shape in the center of the line footprint. An excessively small (<=1m) or large (>20m) value may cause the center line to be positioned close to one of the edges of the footprint.

Ratio of importance between canopy search radius and euclidean distance. A value close to zero (0) prioritizes search radius whereas a value close to one (1) prioritizes euclidean distance. A small value (<=0.1) may cause the forest lines to miss nuances in sparsely vegetated terrain whereas a big value (>=0.5) may overemphasize turns in complex trails. This factor influences final footprint size in a minor way.

Affects the cost of vegetated areas in an exponential fashion. A low (<=1) exponent may lead to lines cutting through corners, whereas a large (>=3) exponent may lead to least cost paths completely avoiding narrow lines.

toolbox.description: Alternative options to some of the Mapping Tools.

tools.name: Corridor Raster
tools.info: Creates a least cost corridor raster between vertices of the input lines. This step can be skipped with the 'Line Footprint' tool.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used to exclude canopy from line footprint.
Input raster image used to calculate the cost corridor.
Maximum processing width for each line. A large value may increase processing times whereas a small value may cause undesired clipping.

If set to False, will process each line from start to end ignoring midpoints, if set to True, will process each segment between each vertex of the input lines separately. The default is False, since it is assumed that the user will manually correct centerlines before running this tool.
Output corridor raster name.

tools.name: Corridor Footprint
tools.info: Creates footprint polygons for each input line based on a least cost corridor raster and individual line thresholds. This step can be skipped with the 'Line Footprint' tool.

parameters.description: Input polyline shapefile.
Input raster image used to exclude canopy from line footprint.
Input corridor raster image where a threshold is applied to generate footprints.
Name of the field (within the input lines) that indicates the least cost corridor thresholds (LCCT).
Maximum processing width for input lines. A large value may increase processing times whereas a small value may cause undesired clipping.
Range used for cell erosion before final polygons are generated. Useful to remove small artifacts. If the cell size is 1m or larger then set this as zero.
Output footprint polygons.
